Title: Contraction Map on Compact Normed Space has a Fixed Point
Content: Let $K$ be a compact normed space  and $f:K\rightarrow K$ such that $$\|f(x)-f(y)\|<\|x-y\|\quad\quad\forall\,\, x, y\in K, x\neq y.$$ Prove that $f$ has a fixed point.
AcceptedAnswer: Edit : Note that $f$ is continuous. (Why?) Define $$g(x)=\lVert f(x)-x\rVert$$ for all $x\in K$. Use the compactness of $K$ to show that $g$ obtains a non-negative minimum. If $f$ has no fixed point, we can then derive a contradiction. (Apologies for my earlier, bogus approach.) You can further show that $f$ has a unique fixed point, if you like.
